prior_works.title: MiniWoB++: A Minimalist Benchmark for Web-based Reinforcement Learning
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided the seminal browser-control benchmark with synthetic tasks, establishing the web navigation problem formulation that WebLINX extends to real, multi-website, multi-turn conversational settings.

prior_works.title: DOM-Q-NET: Grounded Reinforcement Learning on Web Interfaces via Graph Neural Networks
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated element-level modeling of HTML DOM and selective attention over actionable nodes, directly informing WebLINX’s retrieval-inspired strategy to rank and prune HTML elements for tractable LLM inputs.

prior_works.title: WebGPT: Browser-assisted question-answering with human feedback
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed that collecting human demonstrations for browser interactions and training dialogue-driven agents is effective, motivating WebLINX’s multi-turn conversational setup and large-scale expert demos beyond QA.

prior_works.title: Retrieval-Augmented Generation for Knowledge-Intensive NLP
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the paradigm of retrieving relevant context to overcome input length limits, inspiring WebLINX’s retrieval-style ranking to select relevant HTML elements from large web pages for LLM processing.

prior_works.title: WebShop: Towards Scalable Real-World Web Interaction with Grounded Language
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established large-scale goal-oriented web interaction tasks (shopping) and evaluation of language agents, which WebLINX generalizes to broader real-world sites and conversational multi-turn workflows.

prior_works.title: WebArena: A Realistic Web Environment for Building Autonomous Agents
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided a realistic, multi-site web environment highlighting the need for generalist web agents; WebLINX builds on this direction with a larger dialogue-centric dataset and element-pruning pipeline.

prior_works.title: Mind2Web: Towards Generalist Web Agents via Large-Scale Multitask Data
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Presented human demonstrations across real websites to train/evaluate generalist agents, directly motivating WebLINX’s scale (100K interactions) and diversified sites, while adding multi-turn dialogue and retrieval-based HTML selection.

synthesis_narrative:
WebLINX sits at the convergence of three research threads: browser-control benchmarks, realistic web-agent datasets, and retrieval-based context management for LLMs. Early platforms like MiniWoB++ framed web navigation as sequential decision-making over browser UIs, while methods such as DOM-Q-NET introduced element-level reasoning by representing the DOM and selectively focusing on actionable nodes. These ideas underpin WebLINX’s core methodological choice to operate at the granularity of HTML elements.

As the community shifted from synthetic pages to realistic environments, WebShop, WebArena, and Mind2Web broadened task diversity and website coverage with human demonstrations, exposing the scalability and generalization challenges of real-world web agents. WebLINX extends this trajectory by emphasizing multi-turn, dialogue-centric interactions and scaling to 100K interaction steps across 150+ live sites, offering both training data and a rigorous evaluation bed for conversational web navigation.

Finally, WebGPT showed that dialog-driven browsing with human feedback is feasible, but it focused primarily on QA. WebLINX generalizes the conversational paradigm to complex, goal-oriented tasks, and addresses the LLM context bottleneck through a retrieval-inspired ranking that prunes large HTML pages—an idea conceptually aligned with Retrieval-Augmented Generation. By combining dialogue, multimodal signals (screenshots + DOM), action history, and element selection, WebLINX provides a scalable recipe to train and assess agents that imitate expert web navigation under real-world constraints.
